title: Pregnancy and the Human Brain: A Window of Neuroplasticity
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Pregnancy and the Human Brain: A Window of Neuroplasticity," aims to comprehensively map the changes in brain anatomy and function across pregnancy and the postpartum period. The objective is to pinpoint key factors driving pregnancy-related neuroplasticity and reveal neural substrates for potential adaptive and maladaptive processes, with a focus on maternal caregiving, mental health disorders, and memory issues.

The project will employ a prospective cohort study, tracking women from before conception through the postpartum period. Utilizing cutting-edge neuroimaging techniques, psychopedagogic measures, and biomedical assessments, the project aims to provide a foundation for the emerging field of human neuroscience. The potential outcomes of this study will offer unprecedented insights into the neurobiological journey to motherhood, potentially revolutionizing our understanding of pregnancy's impact on the human brain.

This project seeks to pioneer a new frontier in understanding the profound neuroplastic changes that occur during pregnancy. The proposed research could pave the way for improved maternal health care, targeted interventions for postpartum mental health disorders, and a more comprehensive understanding of the cognitive changes that occur during pregnancy. By illuminating the neural underpinnings of motherhood, this project promises to contribute significantly to the broader field of neuroscience and women's health.
